headline: Experiencing bus delays
subhead: The Daily Californian tracked which buses are least predictable
author: Seokhyeon Ryu

sections.text: Sahil Hansalia, a junior, takes the 51B every day to get to class. In the morning, he checks the Transit app on his phone to see when the next bus will arrive. Today, the app predicts the bus will arrive at his stop in 10 minutes. He knows he has a few minutes before leaving his apartment. Most days, the prediction is accurate. But some days, it changes. "I’d say 20 percent of the time, it get pushed back and it’s annoying," Hansalia said. After checking the app five minutes later, he sees the prediction has increased to 12 minutes. He decides to walk to campus instead. Delays like these are common for those who plan their schedules around taking the bus. Particularly near campus and on Shattuck Avenue, there are longer-than-expected wait times for the bus to arrive. Instead of publishing a schedule for each stop on each bus route, AC Transit recommends passengers rely on “real-time” predictions provided by NextBus, a company that partners with transit agencies to provide transit information. AC Transit collects GPS data from its buses and sends the information to NextBus, which predicts departure times for  each stop, taking into account historical traffic patterns, according to the NextBus website. The prediction service is available on AC Transit’s website and the NextBus app. The Transit app shows the same predictions.

sections.caption: A screenshot of the NextBus app. Here, the 51B bus to Berkeley Amtrak is predicted depart from the stop on Bancroft Way and Telegraph Avenue in 2 minutes.

sections.text:
Since most stops don’t have a published schedule, in order to analyze bus delays, The Daily Californian measured the gap between when the NextBus service says a bus is 20 minutes from a stop and when it actually arrives (according to the service). 

Let us say you are at the Bancroft Way and Telegraph Avenue bus stop.

Each arc represents one bus trip, starting 20 minutes before the bus is scheduled to arrive. Below, each chart shows a random selection of 100 trips on a given route, along with the proportion that arrived more than five minutes later than they were predicted to arrive.

Some routes, such as F San Francisco and 18 Lake Merritt BART, have relatively unpredictable arrivals. Others, such as 51B Berkeley Amtrak and 36 West Oakland BART, arrive as predicted more often

Average delay also varies, as F Berkeley experiences close to no delays, on average, while the F San Francisco in the other direction averages several minutes late.

Stops, not just routes, have variation in delay. Delays are highest along Shattuck Avenue southbound and Piedmont Avenue southbound. There is also a noticeably large delay on Bancroft Way and Telegraph Avenue.

The accuracy of predictions is limited by the availability of up-to-the-minute location data, as well as by the unpredictability of traffic patterns and road conditions. Currently, the location of AC Transit buses is recorded and sent to the NextBus service about every two minutes, according to A.J. Martin, a transportation planner at AC Transit. Soon, an upgrade to the tracking technology will enable AC Transit to record and transmit location data every 30 seconds, he said.

AC Transit considers a bus “on time” if it arrives less than five minutes late and not more than one minute early. It aims for its buses to achieve this standard 72 percent of the time. Currently, it is not meeting that goal, according to Martin.

An internal task force meets monthly to address problematic routes, he added, and considers measures to improve timeliness. These include finding ways for buses to jump the queue at traffic lights, installing “transit-only lanes” that give buses priority and installing devices that enable buses to extend the duration of a green light.
